    Continuous Data Table

    Kyle Baron

    2020-06-05

    continuous-table.Rmd

    These functions create summary tables for continuous data. There is a long format and a wide format.

    Long format

    library(pmtables)
library(dplyr)

id <- pmtables:::data("id")

    A summary of covariates

    pt_cont_long(id, cols = "WT,ALB,SCR")
    Variable na Mean Median SDb Min / Max
    All data
    WT 157 70.7 70.0 12.8 43.6 / 97.2
    ALB 156 4.20 4.32 0.793 1.28 / 5.39
    SCR 160 1.36 1.04 0.986 0.710 / 5.59

    a subjects with non-missing values

    b standard deviation

    Paneled summary

    Use the panel argument to split this by, for example, study

    pt_cont_long(
  id,
  cols = "WT,ALB,SCR",
  panel = vars(Study = STUDYf)
)
    Variable na Mean Median SDb Min / Max
    Study: 12-DEMO-001
    WT 29 72.2 70.0 14.3 50.9 / 97.2
    ALB 29 4.28 4.08 0.474 3.56 / 5.15
    SCR 30 1.03 1.04 0.155 0.740 / 1.30
    Study: 12-DEMO-002
    WT 49 72.4 72.1 11.5 51.5 / 96.6
    ALB 50 4.47 4.43 0.468 3.65 / 5.39
    SCR 50 0.971 0.970 0.161 0.720 / 1.30
    Study: 11-DEMO-005
    WT 39 68.9 65.4 14.5 43.6 / 92.8
    ALB 39 4.41 4.44 0.537 3.51 / 5.39
    SCR 40 2.52 2.33 1.43 0.720 / 5.59
    Study: 13-DEMO-001
    WT 40 69.4 68.1 11.6 50.7 / 96.6
    ALB 38 3.58 3.65 1.15 1.28 / 5.38
    SCR 40 0.950 0.975 0.165 0.710 / 1.26
    All data
    WT 157 70.7 70.0 12.8 43.6 / 97.2
    ALB 156 4.20 4.32 0.793 1.28 / 5.39
    SCR 160 1.36 1.04 0.986 0.710 / 5.59

    a subjects with non-missing values

    b standard deviation

    Wide format

    There is also a wide format, where variable names go across the table.

    pt_cont_wide(id, cols = "WT,ALB,SCR")
    WT ALB SCR
    70.7 (12.8) [157] 4.20 (0.793) [156] 1.36 (0.986) [160]
    summary is: mean (standard deviation) [number non-missng]

    We can use the by argument here

    pt_cont_wide(id,cols="WT,ALB,SCR",by = vars(Study = STUDYf))
    Study WT ALB SCR
    12-DEMO-001 72.2 (14.3) [29] 4.28 (0.474) [29] 1.03 (0.155) [30]
    12-DEMO-002 72.4 (11.5) [49] 4.47 (0.468) [50] 0.971 (0.161) [50]
    11-DEMO-005 68.9 (14.5) [39] 4.41 (0.537) [39] 2.52 (1.43) [40]
    13-DEMO-001 69.4 (11.6) [40] 3.58 (1.15) [38] 0.950 (0.165) [40]
    All data 70.7 (12.8) [157] 4.20 (0.793) [156] 1.36 (0.986) [160]
    summary is: mean (standard deviation) [number non-missng]

    Or use by and panel

    pt_cont_wide(
  id,
  cols=vars(WT,ALB,SCR),
  by = vars(Study = STUDYf),
  panel=vars(Sex = SEXf)
)
    Study WT ALB SCR
    Sex: male
    12-DEMO-001 76.3 (16.8) [10] 4.33 (0.468) [10] 1.09 (0.174) [10]
    12-DEMO-002 71.9 (13.4) [17] 4.57 (0.497) [18] 1.01 (0.182) [18]
    11-DEMO-005 69.2 (15.0) [29] 4.46 (0.543) [29] 2.51 (1.46) [29]
    13-DEMO-001 71.1 (13.3) [23] 3.68 (1.01) [22] 0.922 (0.163) [23]
    Sex: female
    12-DEMO-001 70.0 (12.8) [19] 4.25 (0.488) [19] 1.01 (0.141) [20]
    12-DEMO-002 72.6 (10.6) [32] 4.42 (0.450) [32] 0.949 (0.146) [32]
    11-DEMO-005 67.9 (13.3) [10] 4.26 (0.516) [10] 2.53 (1.43) [11]
    13-DEMO-001 67.0 (8.74) [17] 3.45 (1.35) [16] 0.988 (0.164) [17]
    Total
    All data 70.7 (12.8) [157] 4.20 (0.793) [156] 1.36 (0.986) [160]
    summary is: mean (standard deviation) [number non-missng]
